qas.question: In early times, who was generally electied to cardinal?
Why did the ceromony of consecrating a bishop have to be preformed by someone who was already a bishop?
What is the rule if the peson elected is not a bishop?

answers.text: he is consecrated by the Dean of the College of Cardinals, the Cardinal Bishop of Ostia.

qas.question: What happens if a Pope is elected who is not a bishop?

answers.text: he is consecrated by the Dean of the College of Cardinals, the Cardinal Bishop of Ostia.

qas.question: What was reserved for the cardinals in early times?
Who was generally not elected to cardinal in early times?

plausible_answers.text: he is consecrated by the Dean of the College of Cardinals, the Cardinal Bishop of Ostia.

qas.question: What is the rule if the person elected is a bishop?

plausible_answers.text: he is consecrated by the Dean of the College of Cardinals, the Cardinal Bishop of Ostia.

qas.question: What happens if a Nun is elected who is not a bishop?

context: In early times, <b4_0>the privilege of papal election<b4_0/> was not reserved to the cardinals, and for centuries the person elected was customarily <a0_0><b5_0>a Roman priest<b5_0/><a0_0/> and never a bishop from elsewhere. <a1_0>To preserve apostolic succession<a1_0/> the rite of consecrating him a bishop had to be performed by someone who was already a bishop. The rule remains that, if the person elected Pope is not yet a bishop, <a2_0><a3_0><b6_0><b7_0>he is consecrated by the Dean of the College of Cardinals, the Cardinal Bishop of Ostia.
